ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge on the construction of public health and healthcare systems in the United States and Latin American countries, and how this construction contributed to or stemmed from discrimination/mistreatment of marginalized Latine communities in these regions
I developed the knowledge of public health and how it has been historically and contemporary played out in latine border communities.

In Professor Lopez's class, I gained extensive knowledge about the historical aspects of health and disease within the Latino community, both in the United States and globally. Professor Lopez fostered a critical thinking environment that encouraged us to analyze diverse healthcare systems throughout North, Central, South America, and the Caribbean. The assigned readings enabled me to delve deeper into various health models. Additionally, this course helped me recognize the interrelationships between social issues and healthcare.

The course "Disease in the Latinx Borderland" provided a comprehensive understanding of health disparities faced by Latinx populations in borderland regions. It fostered cultural competency, knowledge of border health issues, and research skills to address these disparities. The course also emphasized health advocacy, intersectionality, and community engagement to drive positive change and improve Latinx health outcomes.

This course introduced me to many challenges in healthcare that the Latine community has faced in the past and highlighted some of the currently developing areas where there are disparities in healthcare. This class helps students better understand the history of heathcare in the US and proposes some solutions for the current crisis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Very engaging class discussions and lecture, readings were incredibly interesting

Weaknesses: While readings were interesting, sometimes each week had too much reading for it to be feasibly accomplished and analyzed at the level necessary for meaningful participation in class discussion
The course was great. Good format.
This course has been exceptional, and I perceive no shortcomings. Professor Lopez's facilitation skills are truly remarkable.

The course offers valuable knowledge on health disparities specific to Latinx populations in borderland regions. It fosters cultural competency, research skills, and an understanding of intersectionality and community engagement. The class is very clear and flexible and the course material is very engaging.

The readings were a strength of this course. I found that they provided straightforward and understandable explanations about complex historical events. Class discussion was a weakness of this course, because the professor would present incredible complex questions such as "solve healthcare" expecting students to give educated responses. Since these topics cannot be solved after a single reading, some discussions felt confusing and pointless.
Strengths: The courses covers wide variety of topics.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any student interested in learning the history of American healthcare and public health systems that isn't normally taught in history courses in school.
I would recommend this class to any student who wants to learn more about the medical and public health system and its relation to latine communities.

This course provided invaluable insights into global citizenship, emphasized the importance of health awareness, and granted me the liberty to explore my own perspectives on healthcare reform. I wholeheartedly recommend this course to others.
I would definitely recommend the class. It is very engaging, flexible and the professor is very kind.

I would definitely recommend this course. Professor Lopez-Carrillo is such a sweet, caring person and she does everything to help her students. It's clear she cares about them, and wishes them the best. I will note one thing. The weekly readings are a bit long.
Yes! This course helped me gain a lot of insight on Latinx communities and the challenges they face when it comes to healthcare! I definitely recommend if you are interested in healthcare.
